   [**10-27**] Bile cx NGTD, gram stain no organisms or poly
   CXR [**10-28**] 6:35 AM: ETT in place, about 4 cm from carina, increased
   haziness at both bases, more blunting of costophrenic angle suggestive
   of possible effusion, no clear consolidation
   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to OSH with abdominal pain,
   found to have pancreatitis, and is status-post percutaneous drain,
   intubated overnight for increased work of breathing.
   #) Respiratory failure: Intubated earlier this morning for increased
   work of breathing
oxygen saturation and CXR were not markedly changed.
   Currently on AC 450/14/5 with 100% oxygen.
   - Sending repeat gas to assess for need to change vent settings now
   that patient is intubated and wean FiO2 as permitted.
   .
   #) Pancreatitis: Suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides,
   alcohol use. Also possible that patient could have passed stone given
   dilated CBD.
   - Appreciate surgery consult assistance
no intervention at present.
   - Continue very aggressive IVF resuscitation with 1 L NS boluses, will
   monitor tachycardia, laboratory values to assess adequacy of
   resuscitation; using LR and NS based on chloride, acid-base status,
   potassium/renal function.
   - Central line replaced.
   - Correcting hypocalcemia, calcium gtt, monitoring Q6H.
   - On Zosyn to empirically cover for gram negative pathogens (as
   discussed below).
   - NPO for bowel rest, will consider possibily initiating tube feeds.
   - Sepsis and ARDS risk remain high, continuing to monitor; lactate has
   been WNL.
   .
   #) EtOH abuse: Continuing to monitor for signs of withdrawal given
   possible history of significant consumption. Last known drink was PM of
   [**10-24**]. Likely that LFT abnormalities related as discussed below.
   - Will monitor on CIWA scale, prior to intubation, the importance of
   refraining from alcohol in setting of pancreatitis was stressed.
   .
   #) Acidosis: Patient had had initial bicarbonate of 13 (with normal
   renal function, which was likely due to her renal failure and profound
   hypovolemia from third spacing of fluids, but cannot rule out other
   etiologies as her HCO3 was low prior to her renal insufficiency).
   - Bicarb improved this morning, however patient more acidotic on ABG.
   Will follow up AM ABG post intubation and re-assess as needed.
   .
   #) Hypocalcemia: Patient with marked hypocalcemia, likely due to
   precipitation of calcium in pancreatic bed with fluid sequestration
   into third space. Improving with repletion and hydration.
   - Continue to repleat aggressively, checking Q6H, IV calcium.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient had markedly elevated AST (800s at admission)
   greater than ALT, which is consistent with alcoholic hepatitis pattern.
   Her imaging from the OSH demonstrated fatty liver as well.
   - Will continue to trend LFTs which are markedly improved.
   - Hepatitis serologies pending.
   .
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder: Differential is acalculous
   cholecystitis (less likely given drainage from percutaneous tube),
   cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of pancreas in
   surrounding area. No stones noted on imaging completed at OSH per
   report, and percutaneous drain, which was placed out of concern for
   possible cholangitis, revealed only bile. It is possible she passed
   stone given dilated duct noted.
   - Following cx data
   - Drain in place for now, further recommendations per surgical team
   - Zosyn started given concern for possible infection in setting of
   relative hypotension and bandemia.
   - ERCP team aware of patient.
   #) Gram positive cocci in blood cultures: [**Month (only) 51**] be contaminant or could
   represent superimposed infection. Vancomycin started (day 1 [**10-27**]).
   -          Monitoring all cx data (including from [**Hospital3 **])
   -          Continue vanco until further speciated.
   .
   #) Acute renal failure: Resolved with aggressive fluid resuscitation,
   was likely [**3-6**] to 3^rd spacing of fluids and resultant intravascular
   fluid depletion.
   .
   #) GERD: Continuing IV PPI (NPO)
   .
   #) FEN: NPO, repleting electrolytes as needed. Will discuss TFs,
   aggressive IVFs as noted above.
   .
   #) PPx: On PPI (hx GERD), pneumoboots
   .
   #) Code: Full, confirmed with patient.
   .
   #) Communication: Mom [**Name (NI) 251**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 2017**].
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2162-10-28**] 12:01 AM
   22 Gauge - [**2162-10-28**] 06:27 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2162-10-28**] 06:31 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2162-10-28**] 07:14 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ heparin
   Stress ulcer:  PPI
   VAP:  Chlorhex, mouth hygiene
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full Code
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to the hospital with abdominal pain and was found to have pancreatitis. She was intubated overnight for increased work of breathing and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has a number of medical complications, including:

* Respiratory failure: Intubated for increased work of breathing
* Pancreatitis: Suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides, alcohol use, and possible stone passage
* Acidosis: Patient had initial bicarbonate of 13, but is now more acidotic on ABG
* Hypocalcemia: Likely due to precipitation of calcium in pancreatic bed with fluid sequestration into third space
* Elevated LFTs: Markedly elevated AST and ALT, consistent with alcoholic hepatitis pattern
* Distended, thickened gallbladder: Differential is acalculous cholecystitis, cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of pancreas in surrounding area
* Gram positive cocci in blood cultures: May be contaminant or represent superimposed infection
* Acute renal failure: Resolved with aggressive fluid resuscitation
* GERD: Continuing IV PPI
* FEN: NPO, repleting electrolytes as needed
* PPx: On PPI (hx GERD), pneumoboots

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Sepsis and ARDS risk remain high due to the patient's pancreatitis, acidosis, and hypocalcemia
* Infection: The patient has a central line, arterial line, and urinary catheter, which increases the risk of infection
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is severe and may lead to further complications such as pancreatic necrosis or abscess formation
* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and may require further respiratory support
* Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia may lead to further complications such as muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, or seizures
* Elevated LFTs: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate ongoing liver damage and may lead to further complications such as liver failure
* Distended, thickened gallbladder: The patient's distended, thickened gallbladder may lead to further complications such as cholecystitis or cholangitis
* Gram positive cocci in blood cultures: The patient's gram positive cocci in blood cultures may indicate a superimposed infection and may lead to further complications such as sepsis or endocarditis.

   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to OSH with abdominal pain,
   found to have pancreatitis, and is status-post percutaneous drain,
   intubated overnight for increased work of breathing.
   #) Respiratory failure: Intubated earlier this morning for increased
   work of breathing
oxygen saturation and CXR were not markedly changed.
   Currently on AC 450/14/5 with 100% oxygen.
   - Sending repeat gas to assess for need to change vent settings now
   that patient is intubated and wean FiO2 as permitted.
   .

no intervention at present.

   monitor tachycardia, laboratory values to assess adequacy of
   resuscitation; using LR and NS based on chloride, acid-base status,
   potassium/renal function.
   - Central line replaced.
   - Correcting hypocalcemia, calcium gtt, monitoring Q6H.
   - On Zosyn to empirically cover for gram negative pathogens (as
   discussed below).

   - Sepsis and ARDS risk remain high, continuing to monitor; lactate has
   been WNL.
   .
   #) EtOH abuse: Continuing to monitor for signs of withdrawal given
   possible history of significant consumption. Last known drink was PM of
   [**10-24**]. Likely that LFT abnormalities related as discussed below.
   - Will monitor on CIWA scale, prior to intubation, the importance of
   refraining from alcohol in setting of pancreatitis was stressed.
   .

   renal function, which was likely due to her renal failure and profound
   hypovolemia from third spacing of fluids, but cannot rule out other

   precipitation of calcium in pancreatic bed with fluid sequestration
   into third space. Improving with repletion and hydration.
   - Continue to repleat aggressively, checking Q6H, IV calcium.

   - Will continue to trend LFTs which are markedly improved.
   - Hepatitis serologies pending.
   .

   cholecystitis (less likely given drainage from percutaneous tube),
   cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of pancreas in
   surrounding area. No stones noted on imaging completed at OSH per

   stone given dilated duct noted.

   .

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to the hospital with abdominal pain and was found to have pancreatitis. She was status-post percutaneous drain and intubated overnight for increased work of breathing.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: Intubated and on mechanical ventilation with 100% oxygen.
* Pancreatitis: Suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides, alcohol use, and possible gallstone passage.
* EtOH abuse: History of significant consumption, and the patient is at risk of withdrawal.
* Acidosis: Patient had initial bicarbonate of 13, but her bicarbonate improved this morning.
* Hypocalcemia: Patient has marked hypocalcemia, likely due to precipitation of calcium in the pancreatic bed.
* Elevated LFTs: Patient has markedly elevated AST and ALT, consistent with alcoholic hepatitis pattern.
* Distended, thickened gallbladder: Differential is acalculous cholecystitis, cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of the pancreas.
* Gram positive cocci in blood cultures: May be a contaminant or represent superimposed infection.
* Acute renal failure: Resolved with aggressive fluid resuscitation.
* GERD: Patient is receiving IV PPI.
* FEN: Patient is NPO and repleting electrolytes as needed.
* PPx: Patient is on PPI (hx GERD) and pneumoboots.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and respiratory acidosis.
2. Pancreatitis: Further pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, and sepsis.
3. EtOH withdrawal: Seizures, hallucinations, and cardiovascular instability.
4. Hypocalcemia: Cardiac arrhythmias, muscle cramps, and seizures.
5. Elevated LFTs: Hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and increased risk of bleeding.
6. Distended, thickened gallbladder: Cholangitis, gallstone pancreatitis, and sepsis.
7. Gram positive cocci in blood cultures: Sepsis, endocarditis, and meningitis.
8. Acute renal failure: Chronic kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances, and acidosis.
9. GERD: Aspiration pneumonia, respiratory failure, and esophageal rupture.
10. FEN: Electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, and malnutrition.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiovascular, and metabolic status. She also requires further evaluation and management of her pancreatitis, etOH abuse, and elevated LFTs.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain. She was intubated overnight for increased work of breathing and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a suspected diagnosis of respiratory failure, pancreatitis, and sepsis. She has a large A-a gradient and is at risk for developing ARDS. Her labs show evidence of acidosis, hypocalcemia, and elevated LFTs. She has a distended and thickened gallbladder, and a percutaneous drain has been placed.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may progress to ARDS, which could lead to further respiratory distress and potential mortality.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further pancreatic damage, organ dysfunction, and potential mortality.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress, leading to multi-organ failure, shock, and potential mortality.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further fluid overload, electrolyte imbalance, and potential mortality.
5. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia may worsen, leading to further cardiac and neurological complications.
6. Elevated LFTs: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate ongoing liver damage, which could lead to further liver dysfunction and potential mortality.
7. Distended and Thickened Gallbladder: The patient's distended and thickened gallbladder may be a sign of cholecystitis, which could lead to further complications, such as sepsis and organ failure.
8. Gram-Positive Cocci in Blood Cultures: The presence of gram-positive cocci in the patient's blood cultures may indicate a superimposed infection, which could lead to further complications, such as sepsis and organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as needed to prevent further respiratory distress.
2. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis with aggressive fluid resuscitation and antibiotics.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's sepsis and adjust antibiotics as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's acute renal failure with aggressive fluid resuscitation and electrolyte replacement.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypocalcemia with calcium replacement and monitoring.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's elevated LFTs and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's distended and thickened gallbladder and consider further imaging or surgical intervention as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's gram-positive cocci in blood cultures and adjust antibiotics as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

* The patient is intubated and receiving invasive ventilation due to increased work of breathing.
* The patient has a history of surgery, but no further recommendations have been made.
* The patient has been receiving antibiotics, including Piperacillin and Vancomycin, due to a positive blood culture result.
* The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.5F (36.9C), heart rate of 118 bpm, and blood pressure of 138/81 mmHg.
* The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a PaO2 of 80 mmHg and an FiO2 of 100%.
* The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.
* The patient's imaging studies show haziness at both bases and blunting of the costophrenic angle on the chest X-ray, which may indicate a possible effusion.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation.
* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections due to the patient's compromised immune system.
* Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's positive blood culture result and elevated inflammatory markers.
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying lung disease or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock, due to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulceration or bleeding, due to the patient's critical illness and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
* Neurological complications, such as seizures or altered mental status, due to the patient's underlying medical condition and potential electrolyte imbalances.
* Thrombosis or embolism due to the patient's immobilization and potential hypercoagulable state.

The patient's care plan should focus on addressing these potential complications and ensuring that the patient receives appropriate treatment for their underlying condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU patient who was admitted with septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction. The patient's condition has been unstable, with fluctuations in vital signs and lab results. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and vasopressors. The patient's blood cultures were negative, and the surgical team has decided not to continue Zosyn.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101F (38.3C)
* Heart rate: 95 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 89/62 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 188 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mEq/L
* Electrolytes: 142 mEq/L (sodium), 28.8% (potassium), 3.1 mEq/L (chloride)

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
* Vt (Set): 450 mL
* RR (Set): 22
* PEEP: 8 cmH2O
* FiO2: 50%

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's unstable condition and lack of assessment data.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's lab results show evidence of multi-organ dysfunction, which can lead to further organ failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is high, and the patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which can increase the risk of respiratory failure.
3. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is low, and the patient is receiving vasopressors, which can increase the risk of hemodynamic instability.
4. Infection: The patient's blood cultures were negative, but the patient is still at risk of developing infections, particularly in the respiratory and urinary tracts.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is compromised due to the patient's inability to eat and the use of total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which can indicate renal failure.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to the hospital with abdominal pain and is currently intubated and sedated.

The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, likely secondary to abdominal distension, volume overload, and possibly the beginnings of ARDS. The patient's ABG results show adequate settings, and she is currently on AC 450/22/8 with 50% oxygen.

The patient has also been experiencing pancreatitis, suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides and alcohol use. The patient's LFTs are elevated, consistent with alcoholic hepatitis, and her imaging from the OSH demonstrates fatty liver.

The patient has a distended and thickened gallbladder, which is likely due to acalculous cholecystitis, cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of the pancreas in the surrounding area. The patient's HCT is declining, and it is possible that she is transitioning to hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

The patient has a history of bacteremia, with cultures from the day of admission growing out enterococci faecalis, which was sensitive to vancomycin. The patient's blood cultures are currently negative.

The patient is at risk for sepsis and ARDS, and her lactate levels have been within normal limits. The patient is also at risk for acidosis, hypocalcemia, and GERD.

The patient's current medications include Zosyn, versed, and fentanyl for sedation, and she is receiving TPN and IV fluids. The patient's family was updated on her progress, and they will be contacted with any further questions.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to worsening ARDS or volume overload
* Pancreatitis worsening and potentially leading to hemorrhagic pancreatitis
* Sepsis and ARDS due to ongoing bacteremia or other infections
* Hypocalcemia and acidosis due to ongoing pancreatitis and fluid resuscitation
* GERD and esophageal damage due to prolonged intubation and sedation
* Hemorrhagic pancreatitis due to ongoing pancreatitis and declining HCT
* Bacteremia and sepsis due to ongoing infections
* Worsening liver function due to ongoing pancreatitis and alcohol use
* Nutritional deficiencies due to prolonged NPO status and TPN

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia, who presented to the hospital with abdominal pain and was found to have pancreatitis. She was intubated overnight for increased work of breathing and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has several medical complications, including respiratory failure, pancreatitis, acidosis, hypocalcemia, elevated liver function tests (LFTs), and distended gallbladder.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and the risk of ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome) is high. Close monitoring of oxygen saturation and CXR is essential.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides, alcohol use, and possibly passed stone. Close monitoring of laboratory values and imaging studies is necessary to assess the severity of the pancreatitis.
3. Acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, but close monitoring of bicarbonate levels and pH on ABG is necessary to ensure that acidosis does not recur.
4. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia is likely due to precipitation of calcium in the pancreatic bed with fluid sequestration into third space. Close monitoring of calcium levels and IV calcium supplementation is necessary.
5. Elevated LFTs: The patient's LFTs are elevated, and the differential diagnosis includes alcoholic hepatitis, fatty liver, and secondary to pancreatitis. Close monitoring of LFTs and trending is necessary.
6. Distended gallbladder: The patient's distended gallbladder is likely due to acalculous cholecystitis, cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of the pancreas in the surrounding area. Close monitoring of imaging studies and surgical consult is necessary.
7. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is suspected, and cultures from the day of admission grew out enterococci. Close monitoring of all CX data, including from [**Hospital3 735**], is necessary to ensure that bacteremia does not recur.
8. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure has resolved with aggressive fluid resuscitation, but close monitoring of renal function and electrolyte levels is necessary to ensure that renal failure does not recur.
9. GERD: The patient is receiving IV PPI for GERD, and close monitoring of symptoms and laboratory values is necessary to ensure that GERD is adequately managed.
10. FEN: The patient is NPO and repleting electrolytes as needed, and close monitoring of electrolyte levels and laboratory values is necessary to ensure that FEN is adequately managed.
11. PPx: The patient is receiving PPI for hx GERD, and close monitoring of symptoms and laboratory values is necessary to ensure that PPx is adequately managed.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring of all medical complications is necessary to ensure that she receives appropriate treatment and management.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was admitted to the ICU with abdominal pain and was found to have pancreatitis. She is intubated for increased work of breathing and has been receiving aggressive IV fluid resuscitation. She has developed fevers, and her blood cultures have grown Enterococcus faecalis, which is susceptible to ampicillin, vancomycin, and PCN. Her CT abdomen shows bilateral moderate pleural effusions, increase in amount of ascites, peri-pancreatic stranding and inflammation, and the tip of the appendix appears possibly mildly inflamed.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated for increased work of breathing, and there is a risk of developing ARDS.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient has suspected pancreatitis secondary to high triglycerides and alcohol use, and there is a risk of developing hemorrhage, abscess, or bowel pathology.
3. Fevers and Bacteremia: The patient has continued fevers since admission, and her blood cultures have grown Enterococcus faecalis, which is a high-risk pathogen.
4. Sepsis: The patient is at high risk of developing sepsis due to her fevers, bacteremia, and aggressive IV fluid resuscitation.
5. Anemia: The patient's HCT continues to decline, and there is a risk of developing anemia due to dilutional effects from aggressive IV fluid resuscitation.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a history of pancreatitis, and there is a risk of developing gastrointestinal complications such as cholecystitis, cholangitis, or bowel obstruction.
7. Liver Dysfunction: The patient has elevated LFTs, which may be related to her history of alcohol abuse, and there is a risk of developing liver dysfunction or failure.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient is receiving aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, which may lead to electrolyte imbalance.
9. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing infection due to her fevers, bacteremia, and aggressive IV fluid resuscitation.
10. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient is at risk of developing hemodynamic instability due to her aggressive IV fluid resuscitation and potential sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's fevers and bacteremia, and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust her transfusion therapy as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust her nutrition and hydration therapy as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust her medication therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte balance and adjust her fluid and electrolyte therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust her fluid and vasopressor therapy as needed.
8. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist or hepatologist for further management of the patient's pancreatitis and liver dysfunction.
9. Consider consulting with a infectious disease specialist for further management of the patient's bacteremia and sepsis.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's overall status and adjust her therapy as needed to prevent further complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to the hospital with abdominal pain and was found to have pancreatitis. The patient is currently intubated for respiratory failure and has been diagnosed with pancreatitis, suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides and alcohol use.

The patient's condition is complex and has multiple potential complications. Some of the potential complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated, and there is a risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is likely to worsen, and there is a risk of developing hemorrhagic pancreatitis.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to the presence of enterococci faecalis in the blood and the presence of a percutaneous drain in the pancreas.
4. Cholangitis: There is a risk of developing cholangitis due to the presence of a dilated common bile duct and the possibility of stone passage.
5. Acidosis: The patient has a history of acidosis, which can worsen if not managed properly.
6. Hypocalcemia: The patient has marked hypocalcemia, which can worsen if not managed properly.
7. Elevated LFTs: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which can worsen if not managed properly.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen due to the ongoing bleeding and the risk of developing hemorrhagic pancreatitis.
9. Bacteremia: The patient has a high risk of developing bacteremia due to the presence of enterococci faecalis in the blood.
10. GERD: The patient has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can worsen if not managed properly.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Aggressive IVF resuscitation with lactated Ringer's solution and normal saline.
2. Sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
3. Antibiotics for sepsis and bacteremia.
4. Pain management with morphine and fentanyl.
5. TPN for nutrition.
6. Monitoring of laboratory values, including blood cultures, liver function tests, and electrolyte levels.
7. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and acid-base balance.
8. Consideration of surgery for the patient's pancreatitis and cholecystitis.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical condition. The patient's condition has been evolving over the past 24 hours, with significant changes in their vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies.

The patient's vital signs are unstable, with a temperature of 101.7F (38.7C), heart rate of 90 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 112/59 mmHg. Their respiratory status is also concerning, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96% on 50% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).

Laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 12.9 x 10^9/L, platelet count of 188 x 10^9/L, and lactate level of 0.8 mmol/L. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels. The patient's blood culture results are positive for Enterococcus faecalis, which is susceptible to ampicillin, vancomycin, and piperacillin-tazobactam.

Imaging studies, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen, reveal bilateral moderate pleural effusions, increased ascites, peri-pancreatic stranding and inflammation, and a tip of the appendix that appears possibly mildly inflamed. There is no evidence of abscess, hemorrhage, or bowel pathology.

The patient's clinical condition is concerning, and potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's positive blood culture results and elevated white blood cell count, sepsis is a potential complication.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's CT scan results indicate pancreatitis, which can lead to further complications such as pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, and sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, and they may require further respiratory support to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's abnormal LFTs may indicate hepatic dysfunction, which can lead to further complications such as coagulopathy and encephalopathy.
5. Renal dysfunction: The patient's electrolyte imbalance and elevated creatinine level may indicate renal dysfunction, which can lead to further complications such as acidosis and electrolyte imbalance.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure and heart rate are unstable, which can lead to further complications such as cardiac arrest and arrhythmias.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition that requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to address the patient's ongoing medical issues and improve their clinical condition.

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, potentially complicated by cholangitis/choledocholithiasis and acute renal failure. She is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure, likely related to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has developed bilateral pleural effusions and abdominal ascites, indicating volume overload. She has also had a fever, which has persisted despite the addition of antibiotics, and has undergone imaging studies to rule out abscesses or other sources of infection.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Infection:** The patient's fever and positive blood culture for enterococcus suggest the possibility of ongoing or recurrent infection. The presence of bilateral pleural effusions and abdominal ascites may indicate a septic process.
2. **ARDS:** The patient's respiratory failure and bilateral pleural effusions are consistent with ARDS, which can lead to respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. **Volume Overload:** The patient's bilateral pleural effusions and abdominal ascites indicate volume overload, which can lead to further respiratory distress, cardiac compromise, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. **Pancreatitis:** The patient's pancreatitis may be complicated by pancreatic necrosis, abscesses, or other complications that could lead to further deterioration in her condition.
5. **Renal Failure:** The patient's acute renal failure may not have fully resolved, and further complications such as chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease could develop.
6. **Gallbladder Disease:** The patient's cholangitis/choledocholithiasis may lead to further complications such as biliary obstruction, abscesses, or pancreatitis.
7. **Ethanol Withdrawal:** The patient's history of ethanol abuse may lead to withdrawal symptoms, which could exacerbate her condition.
8. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may be related to volume resuscitation, hemorrhagic pancreatitis, or other causes, and could lead to further complications such as cardiovascular instability.
9. **Coagulopathy:** The patient's elevated fibrinogen and haptoglobin levels may indicate a coagulopathy, which could lead to bleeding complications.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue antibiotics and supportive care to manage the patient's infection and respiratory failure.
2. Initiate diuresis to remove fluid and alleviate volume overload.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider weaning from mechanical ventilation as tolerated.
4. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis and gallbladder disease with antibiotics and supportive care.
5. Consider surgical intervention to address the patient's cholangitis/choledocholithiasis and pancreatitis.
6. Monitor the patient's ethanol withdrawal symptoms and provide supportive care as needed.
7. Consider transfusing blood products to address the patient's anemia and coagulopathy.
8. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and provide supportive care as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female who presents with severe acute pancreatitis, possible cholangitis/choledocholithiasis, and acute renal failure. She has been in the ICU for several days and has undergone various treatments, including antibiotics, fluids, and diuresis. Her current condition is stable, with a CVP of 16 and evidence of anasarca on recent CT scans. She is febrile, with a temperature of 101.7F, and has bilateral pleural effusions with abdominal ascites. Her respiratory status is stable, with an ABG of 7.37/41/107/23/-1, and she is receiving mechanical ventilation. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and liver enzymes, but normal electrolytes and renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Cholangitis/Choledocholithiasis: The patient's possible cholangitis/choledocholithiasis may lead to further complications, such as sepsis, abscess formation, and biliary obstruction.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further hypoxia, hypercapnia, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Infection: The patient's febrile response may indicate the presence of an infection, which may be life-threatening if not treated promptly and effectively.
6. Sepsis: The patient's possible sepsis may lead to further complications, such as organ dysfunction, shock, and potentially life-threatening outcomes.
7. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca may worsen, leading to further fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and potentially life-threatening complications.
8. ETOH Withdrawal: The patient's possible ETOH withdrawal may lead to further complications, such as seizures, hallucinations, and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely, paying attention to changes in her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status.
2. Adjust her treatment plan as necessary to address any worsening of her pancreatitis, cholangitis/choledocholithiasis, respiratory failure, renal failure, infection, sepsis, anasarca, or ETOH withdrawal.
3. Consider consulting with a specialist, such as a gastroenterologist or surgeon, to discuss the patient's treatment plan and potential surgical interventions.
4. Continue to provide aggressive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and diuresis, as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust her treatment plan as necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalances.
6. Consider ordering additional diagnostic tests, such as imaging studies or blood cultures, to further evaluate the patient's condition and guide treatment decisions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis who presents with severe acute pancreatitis and acute renal failure. The patient's condition has been complicated by several issues, including:

1. Fever: The patient's temperature has been elevated to 101.7F (38.7C) overnight, with no clear source identified. The patient's blood cultures from admission grew Enterococcus, but subsequent cultures have been negative. The patient is still experiencing fevers after starting Zosyn.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is likely suffering from ARDS due to underlying pancreatitis, with difficulty keeping up with her minute ventilation due to abdominal distension and bilateral pleural effusions. ABG values have improved with an increase in respiratory rate.
3. Volume overload: The patient has bilateral pleural effusions and abdominal ascites, which is a concern given the patient's history of pancreatitis and acute renal failure.
4. Gallbladder: The patient has a biliary drain in place, and there is concern about possible cholangitis. The patient's bilirubin levels have been increasing, and the biliary drain continues to drain bile.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level has dropped to 9.1 g/dL, likely due to volume resuscitation. The patient is at risk for hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count (WBC) suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and difficulty maintaining minute ventilation can lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
3. Pancreatitis-related complications: The patient's pancreatitis can lead to complications such as hemorrhagic pancreatitis, pancreatic abscess, or pancreatic necrosis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure can worsen if not managed properly, leading to end-stage renal disease.
5. Biliary complications: The patient's gallbladder and biliary drain can lead to complications such as cholangitis, which can be life-threatening.
6. Infection: The patient's history of pancreatitis and abdominal surgery increases the risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
7. Hemorrhage: The patient's anemia and risk of hemorrhagic pancreatitis increase the risk of bleeding, which can be life-threatening.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management by the healthcare team. This includes:

1. Antibiotic therapy: The patient should receive appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent and treat infections.
2. Respiratory support: The patient should receive respiratory support, including oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation, as needed.
3. Fluid management: The patient's fluid management should be closely monitored to prevent volume overload and ensure adequate perfusion.
4. Pain management: The patient should receive adequate pain management to prevent discomfort and reduce the risk of respiratory failure.
5. Nutrition: The patient should receive adequate nutrition, including total parenteral nutrition (TPN), to support her metabolic needs.
6. Blood transfusions: The patient may require blood transfusions to address her anemia and risk of hemorrhage.
7. Imaging: The patient should undergo regular imaging studies, including CT scans and ultrasound, to monitor her condition and detect any complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 40-year-old female who presented to the hospital with abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and hyperlipidemia. She is intubated due to respiratory failure and has a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia. She has been experiencing fevers, bacteremia, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs). The patient has a distended, thickened gallbladder, and her HCT continues to decline.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure: Intubated on 450/22/8 with 50% oxygen, doing well, and no infiltrates on CXR to suggest ARDS.
* Pancreatitis: Suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides, alcohol use, and possible stone passage given dilated CBD.
* Fevers, bacteremia: Continued fevers since admission, culture data revealing enterococcus, and high risk of bacteremia from gut translocation.
* Elevated LFTs: Markedly improved, nearly back to normal range.
* Distended, thickened gallbladder: Differential is acalculous cholecystitis, cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of pancreas in surrounding area.
* Anemia: Patient's HCT continues to decline, although today within laboratory error, likely dilutional from aggressive IVF resuscitation.
* GERD: Continuing IV PPI.
* FEN: NPO, repleting electrolytes as needed, TPN.
* PPx: On PPI (hx GERD), pneumoboots.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Continued need for mechanical ventilation, risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and potential for ARDS.
2. Pancreatitis: Risk of further pancreatic damage, pancreatic abscess, and potential for septic shock.
3. Fevers, bacteremia: Risk of septic shock, multi-organ failure, and potential for prolonged hospitalization.
4. Elevated LFTs: Risk of liver failure, potential for bleeding, and need for close monitoring of liver function.
5. Distended, thickened gallbladder: Risk of gallstone formation, cholangitis, and potential for further complications.
6. Anemia: Risk of further blood loss, potential for transfusion requirements, and need for close monitoring of hemoglobin levels.
7. GERD: Risk of aspiration, potential for respiratory complications, and need for close monitoring of pH levels.
8. FEN: Risk of electrolyte imbalance, potential for further complications, and need for close monitoring of electrolyte levels.
9. PPx: Risk of pneumoboots, potential for further complications, and need for close monitoring of pneumoboots.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
2. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy for suspected pancreatitis and bacteremia.
3. Monitor liver function closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
4. Continue IV PPI for GERD and monitor for signs of aspiration.
5. Monitor electrolyte levels closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue TPN and monitor for signs of malnutrition.
7. Monitor for signs of septic shock and potential for multi-organ failure.
8. Continue to monitor for signs of respiratory failure and potential for ARDS.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a complex medical history. They have undergone several surgical procedures, including a T-tube bile culture, and are receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, pain management, and anticoagulation therapy. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 125/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. They are intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and liver enzymes. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and they have a history of enterococcus infection.

The patient's physical examination is significant for wheezing bilaterally on lung examination, peripheral edema, and mild abdominal distension.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's history of enterococcus infection and wheezing on lung examination, there is a risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and platelet count, along with their history of infection, increase the risk of developing sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's mechanical ventilation and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute suggest that they may be at risk for respiratory failure.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of cardiac surgery and anticoagulation therapy increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as bleeding or arrhythmias.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and intubation increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or brain injury.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of abdominal distension and mild abdominal tenderness increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
7. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's history of anticoagulation therapy and immobility increase the risk of venous thromboembolism.

   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to OSH with abdominal pain,
   found to have pancreatitis, and is status-post percutaneous drain,
   intubated for increased work of breathing, now with fevers.
   #) Respiratory failure: Intubated on [**10-28**] for increased work of
   breathing likely secondary to both due to discomfort of abdominal
   distension (which improved after NG placement), some volume overload,
   and possibly beginnings of ARDS (although no infiltrates on chest
   x-ray).  Currently on AC 450/22/8 with 40% oxygen and doing well,
   appears comfortable. No infiltrates on CXR to suggest ARDS. X-ray today
   as well as CT scan consistent with moderate pleural effusions in
   setting of aggressive IVF resuscitation.
          -      Decreased FiO2 to 40% given last ABG; PS trial.
   -          Sedation with versed and fentanyl.
   -          Given massively fluid overloaded state (from necessary IVFs
   for pancreatitis), initiated diuresis, continue today goal negative 1 L
   today.
   .
   #) Pancreatitis: Suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides,
   alcohol use. Also possible that patient could have passed stone given
   dilated CBD. Calcium, renal function, UOP, BP all stable.
   - Appreciate surgery consult assistance
no intervention at present.
   - Bolus LR if UOP <50, other hemodynamic instability or worsening
   laboratory functions.
   - CT scan consistent with pancreatitis, no hemorrhage or abscess seen.
   - NPO for bowel rest, no tube feeds per surgery recommendations, TPN
   initiated [**10-29**].
   - Sepsis and ARDS risk remain high, continuing to monitor; lactate has
   been WNL.
   - NG tube in place for decompression.
   .
   #) Fevers, bacteremia: Continued fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**]. Culture data
   only revealing for enterococcous.  High risk of bacteremia from gut
   translocation. CT negative for abscess or other concerning pathology.
   Concern also remains for possible cholangitis, although this has felt
   to be less likely. Med effect also possibility (new med would be zosyn,
   versed, fentanyl)
   - Continue zosyn and vancomycin (zosyn started [**10-25**], vancomycin [**10-28**]).
   - Continuing to investigate other potential infection sources (eg lung,
   urine, think about tapping ascites).
   - Re-culture bile, pending.
   - Send c-diff, urine/blood/sputum cx today
   #) EtOH abuse: Continuing to monitor for signs of withdrawal given
   possible history of significant consumption. Last known drink was PM of
   [**10-24**]. Likely that LFT abnormalities related as discussed below.
   -          Continuing versed boluses as needed, currently no signs of
   withdrawal.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient had markedly elevated AST (800s at admission)
   greater than ALT, which is consistent with alcoholic hepatitis pattern.
   Her imaging from the OSH demonstrated fatty liver as well. T. Bili and
   direct bili were elevated which was concerning for worsening abdominal
   process, but they have improved. No stones have been seen on imaging.
   - Will continue to trend LFTs which are markedly improved, nearly back
   to normal range.
   - Hepatitis serologies all negative (HCV, HBV sAg/sAb, HAV.
   .
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder: Differential is acalculous
   cholecystitis (less likely given drainage from percutaneous tube),
   cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of pancreas in
   surrounding area. No stones noted on imaging completed at OSH per
   report, and percutaneous drain, which was placed out of concern for
   possible cholangitis, revealed only bile. It is possible she passed
   stone given dilated duct noted.
   - Following cx data, NGTD from [**Hospital3 735**].
   - Drain in place for now, further recommendations per surgical team
   - Zosyn for fevers, as noted above, (was started [**10-25**], today is day 7).
   - ERCP team aware of patient.
   - Follow up final CT read.
   .
   #) Anemia: Patient
s HCT continues to decline, although today within
   laboratory error. Large degree was likely dilutional from aggressive
   IVF resuscitation. No hemorrhagic component noted on CT.
   - Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, DIC labs all checked.
   - Hct stable
   .
   #) GERD: Continuing IV PPI
   .
   #) FEN: NPO, repleting electrolytes as needed. TPN.
   .
   #) PPx: On PPI (hx GERD), pneumoboots
   .

   .

Based on the provided daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Status:**

* The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia, currently intubated for respiratory failure.
* She has a percutaneous drain in place for pancreatitis and is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and TPN without lipids.
* Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9C, heart rate of 86 bpm, and blood pressure of 125/75 mmHg.
* She has a positive fluid balance, with a total fluid input of 3,117 mL and a total fluid output of 3,610 mL.
* Her respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.
* Her laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, including AST and ALT, consistent with alcoholic hepatitis.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, with ongoing mechanical ventilation and a risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides and alcohol use. The risk of further complications, such as necrosis or abscess formation, remains high.
* Fevers and bacteremia: The patient's fevers are ongoing, and the risk of bacteremia from gut translocation is high. The patient is receiving antibiotic therapy with zosyn and vancomycin.
* Sepsis and ARDS: The patient's sepsis and ARDS risk remain high, and close monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of worsening respiratory or cardiovascular instability.
* Elevated liver enzymes: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, consistent with alcoholic hepatitis. Further monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of worsening liver function.
* Distended gallbladder: The patient's gallbladder is distended and thickened, with a differential diagnosis including acalculous cholecystitis, cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of the pancreas.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin concentration is decreasing, likely due to dilutional anemia from aggressive fluid resuscitation.
* GERD: The patient is receiving IV PPI therapy for GERD.
* FEN: The patient is receiving TPN and electrolyte repletion as needed.
* PPx: The patient is receiving pneumoboots for prophylaxis.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust mechanical ventilation as necessary.
* Continue antibiotic therapy with zosyn and vancomycin.
* Continue to investigate other potential infection sources, including the gut, lungs, and urine.
* Re-culture bile and pending blood cultures.
* Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and hemoglobin concentration.
* Continue to provide nutritional support with TPN and electrolyte repletion as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust IV fluids as necessary.
* Continue to provide prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia, who presented to the hospital with abdominal pain and was diagnosed with pancreatitis. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, and is also experiencing fevers, bacteremia, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient has undergone a percutaneous drain placement and is receiving antibiotics and supportive care.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains intubated and on mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis appears to be improving, but there is still a risk of complications, such as abscess formation or pancreatic necrosis.
3. Bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture for Enterococcus, which may indicate a bacteremia. There is a risk of further septic complications, such as sepsis or septic shock.
4. Elevated Liver Enzymes: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, which may indicate liver damage or inflammation. There is a risk of further liver damage or complications, such as liver failure.
5. Distended Gallbladder: The patient has a distended gallbladder, which may indicate a complication of pancreatitis or cholecystitis. There is a risk of further complications, such as gallbladder rupture or perforation.
6. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is decreasing, which may indicate anemia. There is a risk of further anemia or complications, such as bleeding or blood transfusion requirements.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, which may indicate an imbalance. There is a risk of further electrolyte imbalance or complications, such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk of developing pneumonia due to her intubation and mechanical ventilation.
9. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to her bacteremia and elevated liver enzymes.
10. Liver Failure: The patient is at risk of developing liver failure due to her elevated liver enzymes and pancreatitis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and supportive care for the patient's pancreatitis and bacteremia.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider weaning her off mechanical ventilation when possible.
3. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and electrolyte levels closely and adjust her care accordingly.
4. Consider further imaging studies, such as CT scans or ultrasound, to evaluate the patient's pancreatitis and gallbladder.
5. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist or hepatologist to further evaluate the patient's liver enzymes and pancreatitis.
6. Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to further evaluate the patient's bacteremia and sepsis.
7. Consider referring the patient to a transplant center for further evaluation and treatment of her liver disease.

   dilated CBD. Calcium, renal function, UOP, BP all stable.

no intervention at present.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female who has been admitted to the ICU due to pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia. The patient has a history of pancreatitis, and her current condition is complicated by respiratory failure, pancreatitis, cholangitis, and fevers.

The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains intubated and on assisted ventilation. She has a bilateral pleural effusion, which is being managed with diuresis and pleural drainage.

The patient's pancreatitis is suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides and alcohol use. Her calcium, renal function, and blood pressure are stable, but she has elevated liver enzymes, which are likely related to her history of alcohol abuse.

The patient has a drain in place for cholangitis, and her imaging studies have not shown any evidence of hemorrhage or abscess. She has a history of ethanol abuse and is at risk for withdrawal. Her liver function tests are improving, but she has elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, which may indicate ongoing liver damage.

The patient's anemia is likely related to dilutional anemia from aggressive IV fluid resuscitation. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is being managed with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains at risk for respiratory failure due to her bilateral pleural effusion and ongoing pancreatitis.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is ongoing, and she may be at risk for further complications, such as pancreatic necrosis or abscess.
3. Cholangitis: The patient's cholangitis is being managed with a drain in place, but she may be at risk for further complications, such as sepsis or liver failure.
4. Fevers: The patient's fevers are ongoing, and she may be at risk for further complications, such as bacteremia or sepsis.
5. Ethanol withdrawal: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is at risk for withdrawal, which can lead to seizures, hallucinations, and other complications.
6. Liver damage: The patient's liver function tests are improving, but she has elevated LDH levels, which may indicate ongoing liver damage.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to dilutional anemia from aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, but she may also be at risk for further complications, such as bleeding or cardiovascular instability.

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Respiratory support: The patient will continue to receive assisted ventilation and oxygen therapy to manage her respiratory failure.
2. Pancreatitis management: The patient will continue to receive TPN and antibiotics to manage her pancreatitis.
3. Cholangitis management: The patient will continue to receive a drain in place to manage her cholangitis.
4. Fever management: The patient will continue to receive antibiotics and antipyretics to manage her fevers.
5. Ethanol withdrawal management: The patient will continue to receive sedation and other medications to manage her ethanol withdrawal symptoms.
6. Liver damage management: The patient will continue to receive TPN and other medications to manage her liver damage.
7. Anemia management: The patient will continue to receive blood transfusions and other medications to manage her anemia.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia.
* She is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure.
* She has a percutaneous drain in place, and her abdominal distension has improved after NG tube placement.
* She has fevers, bacteremia, and a rising white count and bandemia.
* Her liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, consistent with alcoholic hepatitis.
* She has a distended and thickened gallbladder, which may be due to acalculous cholecystitis, cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of the pancreas.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she may still require mechanical ventilation.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and potential complications such as abscesses or hemorrhage.
* Cholangitis: The patient's cholangitis may progress, leading to sepsis and potential complications such as liver abscesses or septic shock.
* Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia may lead to sepsis and potential complications such as endocarditis or meningitis.
* Liver failure: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate liver failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and potential complications such as bleeding or ascites.
* Gallbladder complications: The patient's distended and thickened gallbladder may lead to complications such as cholecystitis, cholangitis, or gallstone formation.

**Recommendations:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis and cholangitis with antibiotics and drainage as indicated.
* Monitor the patient's LFTs and adjust treatment as needed to prevent liver failure.
* Continue to monitor the patient's bacteremia and adjust treatment as needed to prevent sepsis.
* Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's gallbladder and potential complications.
* Continue to manage the patient's electrolyte imbalance and potential complications such as bleeding or ascites.

**Next Steps:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
* Adjust treatment as needed to prevent potential complications.
* Consider further consultation with surgical and gastroenterology teams to optimize management of the patient's pancreatitis and cholangitis.
* Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's gallbladder and potential complications.
* Continue to provide supportive care, including nutrition and glycemic control, to optimize the patient's overall condition.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was admitted to the ICU with abdominal pain and respiratory failure. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 95%, and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, including aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT), which are consistent with alcoholic hepatitis. Her imaging studies show bilateral pleural effusions, and she has a percutaneous drain in place for suspected cholangitis.

The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to her prolonged mechanical ventilation and respiratory failure. Her blood cultures are positive for Enterococcus, and she has a rising white blood cell count and bandemia, indicating ongoing infection.

The patient's pancreatitis is suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides and alcohol use, and she has a dilated common bile duct (CBD) on imaging studies. She has a percutaneous drain in place, which was placed to drain the CBD, but it did not reveal any stones or infection.

The patient's anemia is likely due to dilutional effects from aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation, and her hemoglobin level is declining. She is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and has a nasogastric tube in place for decompression.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate due to ongoing infection, respiratory failure, or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction or failure.
3. Cholangitis: The patient's cholangitis may progress, leading to sepsis, organ failure, or death.
4. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia may spread to other parts of her body, leading to sepsis, organ failure, or death.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction or failure.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or other complications.
7. Hepatitis: The patient's hepatitis may progress, leading to liver failure or death.
8. Pancreatic abscess: The patient may develop a pancreatic abscess, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, or death.
9. Sepsis: The patient may develop sepsis, which can lead to organ failure, shock, or death.

To mitigate these complications, the patient should continue to receive aggressive treatment for her underlying conditions, including antibiotics, fluids, and respiratory support. Regular monitoring of her laboratory results, imaging studies, and clinical status is essential to adjust her treatment plan and prevent complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia, who is currently intubated in the ICU due to respiratory failure. The patient's condition has been complicated by fevers, bacteremia, and pancreatitis, which is suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides and alcohol use.

The patient's recent events include unplanned extubation, which was promptly reintubated after oxygen saturations dropped to low 80s. The patient's respiratory support includes a ventilator with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and 40% oxygen.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 14.7
* Hct: 26.1
* Plt: 230
* Cr: 0.8
* TCO2: 25
* Glucose: 140
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 12.9/29.2/1.1, ALT / AST: 36/34, Alk Phos / T Bili: 125/0.6, Amylase / Lipase: 40/97

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray: No infiltrates to suggest ARDS
* CT scan: Consistent with moderate pleural effusions and pancreatitis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Decreased FiO2 to 40% given last ABG
* Sedation with versed and fentanyl
* Initiated diuresis to manage fluid overload
* Continue TPN and NPO for bowel rest
* Continue zosyn and vancomycin for fevers and bacteremia
* Re-culture bile and send c-diff, urine/blood/sputum cx today
* Monitor for signs of withdrawal given possible history of significant ethanol consumption

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to pancreatitis and respiratory acidosis
* Bacteremia and sepsis due to gut translocation and high risk of infection
* Pancreatitis and cholangitis due to gallbladder distension and thickening
* Elevated LFTs due to liver damage and possible hepatitis
* Anemia due to dilutional anemia and possible blood loss
* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) due to increased risk of aspiration
* FEN (fatty liver disease) due to pancreatitis and liver damage
* Pneumoboots due to respiratory failure and mechanical ventilation
* Code status: Full, confirmed with patient

The patient's family was updated on her progress, and they will be notified of any changes or concerns. The patient's father will be kept informed of her status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-inch tall individual who has been admitted to the ICU due to pancreatitis. The patient has been on TPN without lipids and has been receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and Zosyn, which has been stopped due to the patient's susceptibility to ampicillin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7C, heart rate of 92 bpm, and blood pressure of 132/78 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95% on 40% FiO2.

The patient has had an unplanned extubation, which was promptly reintubated after the patient's oxygen saturation dropped to the low 80s. The patient had failed a previous spontaneous breathing trial (PS) with tachypnea and low volumes.

The patient's laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. The patient's liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, are elevated. The patient's serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen are within normal limits.

The patient's medical history is significant for pancreatitis, and the patient has been receiving TPN and antibiotics. The patient's family history is significant for pancreatitis.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's unplanned extubation and subsequent reintubation indicate that the patient is at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient's pancreatitis and the presence of enterococci in the blood culture indicate that the patient is at risk for infection.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and the presence of enterococci in the blood culture indicate that the patient is at risk for sepsis.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is a potential source of infection and organ failure.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's TPN without lipids may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not managed properly.
6. Medication side effects: The patient's medications, including antibiotics and TPN, may cause side effects that could worsen the patient's condition.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including respiratory failure, infection, sepsis, pancreatitis, nutritional deficiencies, and medication side effects. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent these complications and improve the patient's outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who presented to OSH with abdominal pain,
   found to have pancreatitis, and is status-post percutaneous drain,
   intubated for increased work of breathing, now with fevers.
   #) Respiratory failure: Intubated on [**10-28**] for increased work of
   breathing likely secondary to both due to discomfort of abdominal
   distension (which improved after NG placement), some volume overload,
   and possibly beginnings of ARDS (although no infiltrates on chest
   x-ray).  Currently on AC 450/22/8 with 40% oxygen and doing well,
   appears comfortable. No infiltrates on CXR to suggest ARDS. X-ray today
   as well as CT scan consistent with moderate pleural effusions in
   setting of aggressive IVF resuscitation. Last ABG at 4:30 AM: pH 7.41,
   pCO2 48, pO2 80, HCO3 31
          -      Decreased FiO2 to 40% given last ABG; PS trial.
   -          Sedation with versed and fentanyl.
   -          Given massively fluid overloaded state (from necessary IVFs
   for pancreatitis), initiated diuresis, continue today goal negative 1 L
   today.
   .
   #) Pancreatitis: Suspected to be secondary to high triglycerides,
   alcohol use. Also possible that patient could have passed stone given
   dilated CBD. Calcium, renal function, UOP, BP all stable.
   - Appreciate surgery consult assistance
no intervention at present.
   - Bolus LR if UOP <50, other hemodynamic instability or worsening
   laboratory functions.
   - CT scan consistent with pancreatitis, no hemorrhage or abscess seen.
   - NPO for bowel rest, no tube feeds per surgery recommendations, TPN
   initiated [**10-29**].
   - Sepsis and ARDS risk remain high, continuing to monitor; lactate has
   been WNL.
   - NG tube in place for decompression.
   .
   #) Fevers, bacteremia: Continued fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**]. Culture data
   only revealing for enterococcous.  High risk of bacteremia from gut
   translocation. CT negative for abscess or other concerning pathology.
   Concern also remains for possible cholangitis, although this has felt
   to be less likely. Med effect also possibility (new med would be zosyn,
   versed, fentanyl)
   - Continue zosyn and vancomycin (zosyn started [**10-25**], vancomycin [**10-28**]).
   - Continuing to investigate other potential infection sources (eg lung,
   urine, think about tapping ascites).
   - Re-culture bile, pending.
   - Send c-diff, urine/blood/sputum cx today
   #) EtOH abuse: Continuing to monitor for signs of withdrawal given
   possible history of significant consumption. Last known drink was PM of
   [**10-24**]. Likely that LFT abnormalities related as discussed below.
   -          Continuing versed boluses as needed, currently no signs of
   withdrawal.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient had markedly elevated AST (800s at admission)
   greater than ALT, which is consistent with alcoholic hepatitis pattern.
   Her imaging from the OSH demonstrated fatty liver as well. T. Bili and
   direct bili were elevated which was concerning for worsening abdominal
   process, but they have improved. No stones have been seen on imaging.
   - Will continue to trend LFTs which are markedly improved, nearly back
   to normal range.
   - Hepatitis serologies all negative (HCV, HBV sAg/sAb, HAV.
   .
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder: Differential is acalculous
   cholecystitis (less likely given drainage from percutaneous tube),
   cholangitis, or secondary to edema and irritation of pancreas in
   surrounding area. No stones noted on imaging completed at OSH per
   report, and percutaneous drain, which was placed out of concern for
   possible cholangitis, revealed only bile. It is possible she passed
   stone given dilated duct noted.
   - Following cx data, NGTD from [**Hospital3 735**].
   - Drain in place for now, further recommendations per surgical team
   - Zosyn for fevers, as noted above, (was started [**10-25**], today is day 7).
   - ERCP team aware of patient.
   - Follow up final CT read.
   .
   #) Anemia: Patient
s HCT continues to decline, although today within
   laboratory error. Large degree was likely dilutional from aggressive
   IVF resuscitation. No hemorrhagic component noted on CT.
   - Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, DIC labs all checked.
   - Hct stable
   .
   #) GERD: Continuing IV PPI
   .
   #) FEN: NPO, repleting electrolytes as needed. TPN.
   .
   #) PPx: On PPI (hx GERD), pneumoboots
   .
   #) Code: Full, confirmed with patient.
   .
   #) Communication: Family was in, was updated on progress, all questions
   answered, they will call anytime with questions. Per patient
s parents,
   updates should be relayed to patient
