   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient is now status-post tracheostomy after
   difficulty weaning. She did well on PS trials yesterday, however has
   been intermittently agitated which has limited ability to further wean.
   - Discussed strategy for weaning sedation and minimizing risk of
   withdrawal from narcotics and benzodiazepines, and will increase haldol
   to 3 mg TID standing, given she has a good response to this, and
   uptitrate if needed so that PRNs are minimized. Continuing valium 10 mg
   PO TID, and will plan to go up further if needed to wean versed once
   she is on a stable haldol dose. Fentanyl patch should begin to take
   effect later today or tomorrow, so will wean fentanyl as tolerated at
   that time. Continuing methadone as well, will aim to further titrate
   that down once above interventions made. Following daily QTc given
   haldol and methadone can both prolong this.
   - Continue to work on diuresis goal about 500cc-1000cc.
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment as noted below.
   - 1:1 sitter to help re-orient patient to ensure safety of her lines
   and tracheostomy and hopefully further safely wean sedation since this
   has been a major barrier.
   - Speech consult for assistance with PMV if she tolerates trach mask,
   which may help patient speak and become more oriented, less agitated.
   .
   #) Fevers, bacteremia:
   Overall fever curve appears to be improving.
   She has had fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**]. Work up has included a TTE which
   was negative for abscess or vegetation. Lines have been changed and
   PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound revealed there was not
   enough fluid for a paracentesis last week, and again this was
   consistent with CT this week. Bandemia appeared to have improved since
   initiation of flagyl. She has completed 14 day course of zosyn
   ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which covered entercoccous in one blood culture.
   Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia,
   especially given klebseilla in sputum.
   - Appreciate ID recommendations
   - Following all culture data, including surveillance cultures.
   - Status post 14 day course of empiric flagyl (last day today) for
   question of c. difficile infection.
   - Given sensitivities and imaging, cipro stopped. Sputum klebsiella is
   very sensitive to meropenem (day 6) for VAP.
   - Will continue vancomycin for gram positive blood cultures--?
   .
   #) EtOH abuse: Last known drink was PM of [**10-24**]. Sedation taper and
   transition as noted above. Folate and thiamine supplementation. Social
   work consult once extubated.
   .
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder:  No acute issues at present. Her
   cholecystitis has been felt to be related to edema from her
   pancreatitis, and no stones have been seen on repeated imaging. At OSH,
   a percutaneous drain was placed out of concern for possible
   cholangitis, revealed only bile. Patient has since pulled out the
   percutaneous tube, and no further intervention has been deemed
   necessary; surgical team has since removed the suture material that
   remained.
   -          Cholecystectomy in [**5-9**] weeks after recovers from acute
   illness.
   .
   #) Anemia: Stable HCT this week. No evidence of bleeding currently, and
   she has not had any evidence of a hemorrhagic component of her
   pancreatitis noted on CT previously. Phlebotomy is likely playing at
   least a small role as well. No evidence of hemorrhage on repeat imaging
   study.
   - Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, DIC labs all checked, iron
   studies consistent with anemia of chronic disease, B12/folate WNL.
   - HCT stable, continuing to follow trend.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, patient
s INR had slowly trended upward,
   suspect likely secondary to nutritional deficiencies given that patient
   was NPO, then only on TPN. She has received Vitamin K.
   .
   #) Eosinophilia: Noted on today
s labs. Mild, will continue to monitor
   trend, could be related to medications (meropenem is new).
   .
   #) GERD: PO PPI
   .
   #) FEN: Tube
   feeds
   .
   #) PPx: On PPI (hx GERD), pneumoboots
   .
   #) Code: Full, confirmed with patient.
   .
   #) Communication: Family (mother and father), mom [**Name (NI) 251**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 2180**]. Discussed events and updated father this morning via nursing
   team, family will be in to visit today with patient
s son.

   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued

   #) Respiratory failure: Patient is now status-post tracheostomy after
   difficulty weaning. She did well on PS trials yesterday, however has
   been intermittently agitated which has limited ability to further wean.
   - Discussed strategy for weaning sedation and minimizing risk of
   withdrawal from narcotics and benzodiazepines, and will increase haldol
   to 3 mg TID standing, given she has a good response to this, and
   uptitrate if needed so that PRNs are minimized. Continuing valium 10 mg
   PO TID, and will plan to go up further if needed to wean versed once
   she is on a stable haldol dose. Fentanyl patch should begin to take
   effect later today or tomorrow, so will wean fentanyl as tolerated at
   that time. Continuing methadone as well, will aim to further titrate
   that down once above interventions made. Following daily QTc given
   haldol and methadone can both prolong this.

   PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound revealed there was not

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver function tests. She is intubated and has a tracheostomy. The patient has been experiencing periods of agitation, which has limited her ability to further wean from the ventilator. She has been diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia and has completed a 14-day course of empiric flagyl for possible Clostridioides difficile infection.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, anemia, and eosinophilia. She has also been experiencing fevers, which appear to be improving. Her INR has been stable, and she has received Vitamin K. The patient's medication list includes various antibiotics, antifungals, and sedatives.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's inability to wean from the ventilator due to agitation and sedation withdrawal may lead to respiratory failure.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient's diagnosis of ventilator-associated pneumonia increases her risk of developing further complications, such as sepsis and multi-organ failure.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not addressed, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues and organs.
4. Eosinophilia: The patient's mild eosinophilia may be a sign of an allergic reaction or an underlying condition, such as parasitic infection.
5. Elevated INR: The patient's stable INR may be a sign of ongoing bleeding or coagulopathy, which requires close monitoring.
6. Fevers: The patient's ongoing fevers may indicate the presence of an underlying infection or inflammatory condition, which requires further investigation and treatment.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of pancreatitis and gallbladder edema increases her risk of developing further gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, or abscesses.
8. Sedation withdrawal: The patient's sedation taper and transition may lead to withdrawal symptoms, such as agitation, anxiety, and insomnia.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's history of pancreatitis and gastrointestinal edema may lead to malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances, which require close monitoring and supplementation.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia, currently admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, fevers, bacteremia, and anemia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38C (100.4F), blood pressure of 126/98 mmHg, heart rate of 98 bpm, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 13.2 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 599 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* Total bilirubin: 0.6 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.1 g/dL
* LDH: 262 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, vancomycin, and meropenem, for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). She has also received antifungal therapy for suspected fungal infection.

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl patch
* Methadone
* Haldol
* Valium
* Lanzoprazole
* Thiamine
* Folate
* Versed
* Hep Sub Q
* Lasix

The patient's medical history includes pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs). She has a history of alcohol abuse and hyperlipidemia.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

* Respiratory failure
* Fevers and bacteremia
* Anemia
* Elevated INR
* Eosinophilia
* Distended and thickened gallbladder
* Cholecystitis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Further diuresis to assist with weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Sedation taper and transition to minimize risk of withdrawal from narcotics and benzodiazepines
* Fentanyl patch to take effect later today or tomorrow
* Methadone titration to reduce dose
* Speech consult for assistance with tracheostomy weaning
* 1:1 sitter to help re-orient the patient and ensure safety
* Cholecystectomy in 5-9 weeks after recovering from acute illness
* Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, and DIC labs to monitor anemia
* Vitamin K to correct elevated INR
* Monitoring of eosinophilia trend

The patient's ICU care includes nutrition with Peptamen 1.5, glycemic control with regular insulin sliding scale, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP. The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred to the ICU for pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver function tests. She was intubated for increased work of breathing and has a tracheostomy in place. The patient has been experiencing periods of agitation and has been treated with Haldol and Valium. She has also been receiving antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.5F, heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure of 131/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. Her respiratory support includes a tracheostomy tube and mechanical ventilation.

The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is currently receiving folate and thiamine supplementation. She has a distended and thickened gallbladder, which is being managed conservatively. The patient's anemia is being monitored, and her INR is stable. She has mild eosinophilia, which is being monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver function tests, which are being monitored. Her blood cultures have been positive for coagulase-negative staph, and she is receiving vancomycin. She has also been receiving meropenem for VAP.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's VAP is being treated with antibiotics, and she is being monitored for signs of infection.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is being managed conservatively, and she is being monitored for signs of complications.
3. Gallbladder disease: The patient's distended and thickened gallbladder is being managed conservatively, and she is being monitored for signs of complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is being monitored, and she is receiving folate and thiamine supplementation.
5. Eosinophilia: The patient's mild eosinophilia is being monitored, and its cause is being investigated.
6. INR elevation: The patient's INR is stable, but it is being monitored for signs of bleeding or other complications.
7. Ethanol withdrawal: The patient is being monitored for signs of ethanol withdrawal, and she is receiving folate and thiamine supplementation.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is being managed with mechanical ventilation, and she is being monitored for signs of improvement.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for VAP and monitor for signs of infection.
2. Continue to manage pancreatitis conservatively and monitor for signs of complications.
3. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's eosinophilia and investigate its cause.
5. Monitor the patient's INR and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's ethanol withdrawal symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical history. They have been admitted with a PICC line inserted, which was placed on Sunday morning. The patient has been diuresing and is receiving various medications, including Haldol, Fentanyl, and Midazolam. They have also been receiving antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Meropenem, and Metronidazole.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.5F, heart rate of 100 bpm, and blood pressure of 131/67 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy and are being ventilated with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.9 K/uL, a hematocrit of 23.8%, and a platelet count of 622 K/uL. Their electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 5.8 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination is notable for the presence of a tracheostomy tube, which is in place. They are alert and follow commands, with no signs of respiratory distress.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged ventilation and the presence of a tracheostomy tube, there is a risk of developing VAP.
2. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): The patient's PICC line has been in place for several days, increasing the risk of CLABSI.
3. Catheter-related urinary tract infection (UTI): The patient's indwelling urinary catheter increases the risk of developing a UTI.
4. DVT/PE: The patient's immobility and presence of a central line increase the risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
5. Medication-related side effects: The patient is receiving multiple medications, including sedatives and analgesics, which can have side effects such as respiratory depression, hypotension, and gastrointestinal disturbances.
6. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid balance is critical, and any imbalance can lead to respiratory distress, cardiovascular instability, or renal failure.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels, particularly potassium, are slightly elevated, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
8. Infection: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and immobility increase the risk of developing a secondary infection, such as sepsis or pneumonia.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient is now status-post tracheostomy after
   difficulty weaning. Saturday she did not do well with a spontaneous
   breathing trial.
   - Haldol appeared to work well with improvement during the day in
   regards to her agitation. Given that the patient tends to become more
   agitated and restless overnight, increased PM haldol dose to 10 mg, and
   give Q6H dosing of 5 mg during the day. Continuing valium 10 mg PO TID,
   and will plan to go up further if needed to wean versed once she is on
   a stable haldol dose (today making additional adjustments). Continuing
   fentanyl patch, and will aim to wean versed by 20% today (down to 4).
   Following daily QTc given haldol and methadone can both prolong this.
   - Continue to work on diuresis goal about 500cc-1000cc.
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment as noted below.
   - 1:1 sitter to help re-orient patient to ensure safety of her lines
   and tracheostomy and hopefully further safely wean sedation since this
   has been a major barrier.
   - Speech consult for assistance with PMV once she tolerates trach mask,
   which may help patient speak and become more oriented, less agitated.
   - [**6-7**] trial today.
   .
   #) Fevers, bacteremia:
   Continues to have intermittent low grade temperatures (100), but as
   noted yesterday, fever curve appears to be improving.
   She has had fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**]. Work up has included a TTE which
   was negative for abscess or vegetation. Lines have been changed and
   PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound revealed there was not
   enough fluid for a paracentesis last week, and again this was
   consistent with CT completed last week. Bandemia appeared to have
   improved since initiation of flagyl. She has completed 14 day course of
   zosyn ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which covered entercoccous in one blood culture.
   Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia,
   especially given klebseilla in sputum.
   - Appreciate ID recommendations
   - Following all culture data, including surveillance cultures.
   - Status post 14 day course of empiric flagyl (last day today) for
   question of c. difficile infection.
   - Given sensitivities and imaging, cipro stopped. Sputum klebsiella is
   very sensitive to meropenem for VAP.
   - Will continue vancomycin for gram positive blood cultures which were
   coagulase negative staph until sensitivities return. Given that she has
   had two positive cultures, cannot solely attribute this to
   contamination, however surveillance cultures have been negative. Prior
   TTE was negative, but will need to consider repeat if patient remains
   febrile or additional culture return positive.
   - PLAN: Vanco for 14 day total course (Staph bacteremia) + Meropenem
   for 8 day total course (Klebs)
   .
   #) EtOH abuse: Last known drink was PM of [**10-24**]. Sedation taper and
   transition as noted above. Folate and thiamine supplementation. Social
   work consult once more awake and on PMV.
   .
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder:  No acute issues at present. Her
   cholecystitis has been felt to be related to edema from her
   pancreatitis, and no stones have been seen on repeated imaging. At OSH,
   a percutaneous drain was placed out of concern for possible
   cholangitis, revealed only bile. Patient has since pulled out the
   percutaneous tube, and no further intervention has been deemed
   necessary; surgical team has since removed the suture material that
   remained.
   -          Cholecystectomy in [**5-9**] weeks after recovers from acute

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient is now status-post tracheostomy after
   difficulty weaning. Saturday she did not do well with a spontaneous
   breathing trial.
   - Haldol appeared to work well with improvement during the day in
   regards to her agitation. Given that the patient tends to become more
   agitated and restless overnight, increased PM haldol dose to 10 mg, and
   give Q6H dosing of 5 mg during the day. Continuing valium 10 mg PO TID,
   and will plan to go up further if needed to wean versed once she is on
   a stable haldol dose (today making additional adjustments). Continuing
   fentanyl patch, and will aim to wean versed by 20% today (down to 4).
   Following daily QTc given haldol and methadone can both prolong this.
   - Continue to work on diuresis goal about 500cc-1000cc.
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment as noted below.
   - 1:1 sitter to help re-orient patient to ensure safety of her lines
   and tracheostomy and hopefully further safely wean sedation since this
   has been a major barrier.
   - Speech consult for assistance with PMV once she tolerates trach mask,
   which may help patient speak and become more oriented, less agitated.
   - [**6-7**] trial today.
   .
   #) Fevers, bacteremia:
   Continues to have intermittent low grade temperatures (100), but as
   noted yesterday, fever curve appears to be improving.
   She has had fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**]. Work up has included a TTE which
   was negative for abscess or vegetation. Lines have been changed and
   PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound revealed there was not
   enough fluid for a paracentesis last week, and again this was
   consistent with CT completed last week. Bandemia appeared to have
   improved since initiation of flagyl. She has completed 14 day course of
   zosyn ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which covered entercoccous in one blood culture.
   Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia,
   especially given klebseilla in sputum.
   - Appreciate ID recommendations
   - Following all culture data, including surveillance cultures.
   - Status post 14 day course of empiric flagyl (last day today) for
   question of c. difficile infection.
   - Given sensitivities and imaging, cipro stopped. Sputum klebsiella is
   very sensitive to meropenem for VAP.
   - Will continue vancomycin for gram positive blood cultures which were
   coagulase negative staph until sensitivities return. Given that she has
   had two positive cultures, cannot solely attribute this to
   contamination, however surveillance cultures have been negative. Prior
   TTE was negative, but will need to consider repeat if patient remains
   febrile or additional culture return positive.
   - PLAN: Vanco for 14 day total course (Staph bacteremia) + Meropenem
   for 8 day total course (Klebs)
   .

   transition as noted above. Folate and thiamine supplementation. Social

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs). She has been intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 131/67 mmHg, heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98%.
* Neurological status: The patient is awake and interactive, but has periods of agitation and restlessness.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 13.9 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin is 7.9 g/dL, and platelet count is 622 x 10^9/L. Her liver function tests are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 545 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 97 mg/dL.
* Imaging studies: The patient has undergone a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen, which showed gallbladder edema and pancreatitis. A chest X-ray (CXR) has been performed, which showed a PICC line in place.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Pancreatitis: The patient has a history of pancreatitis, which is a potentially life-threatening condition.
* Gallbladder edema: The patient has gallbladder edema, which can lead to complications such as cholangitis or cholecystitis.
* Elevated liver function tests: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, which can indicate liver damage or dysfunction.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, which can be caused by bleeding, nutritional deficiencies, or other underlying medical conditions.
* Eosinophilia: The patient has eosinophilia, which can be caused by medications or underlying medical conditions.
* Elevated INR: The patient's international normalized ratio (INR) is elevated, which can indicate bleeding or coagulopathy.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, and the plan is to wean her off the ventilator once her respiratory status improves.
* Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for VAP and other potential infections.
* Pain management: The patient is receiving pain management medication to control her agitation and restlessness.
* Nutrition: The patient is receiving tube feedings, and the plan is to transition her to oral feedings once her respiratory status improves.
* Stress ulcer prophylaxis: The patient is receiving stress ulcer prophylaxis medication to prevent stress ulcers.

The patient's potential complications include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP, which can be a life-threatening condition.
* Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to her anemia and elevated INR.
* Liver damage: The patient's elevated liver function tests can indicate liver damage or dysfunction, which can lead to complications such as liver failure.
* Kidney damage: The patient's elevated creatinine level can indicate kidney damage or dysfunction, which can lead to complications such as acute kidney injury.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical conditions and potential complications. Her treatment plan includes mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, pain management, nutrition, and stress ulcer prophylaxis. The patient's potential complications include VAP, bleeding, liver damage, and kidney damage.

   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient is now status-post tracheostomy after
   difficulty weaning. Diuresed yesterday with good results. More
   comfortable this AM. Will trial T-piece with PS 0.
   - Discussed strategy for weaning sedation and minimizing risk of
   withdrawal from narcotics and benzodiazepines, and will increase haldol
   to 5 mg [**Hospital1 7**] standing, 10mg at bedtime - which has worked well.
   Continuing valium 10 mg PO TID, and will plan to go up further if
   needed to wean versed once she is on a stable haldol dose. Fentanyl
   patch in place. Continuing methadone as well, will aim to further
   titrate that down once above interventions made. Following daily QTc
   given haldol and methadone can both prolong this.
   - Continue to work on diuresis goal about 500cc-1000cc.
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment as noted below.
   - 1:1 sitter to help re-orient patient to ensure safety of her lines
   and tracheostomy and hopefully further safely wean sedation since this
   has been a major barrier.
   - Speech consult for assistance with PMV if she tolerates trach mask,
   which may help patient speak and become more oriented, less agitated.
   .

   Overall fever curve appears to be improving.
   She has had fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**] but afebrile today.  Work up has
   included a TTE which was negative for abscess or vegetation. Lines have
   been changed and PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound
   revealed there was not enough fluid for a paracentesis last week, and
   again this was consistent with CT this week. Bandemia appeared to have
   improved since initiation of flagyl. She has completed 14 day course of
   zosyn ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which covered entercoccous in one blood culture.
   Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia,

   - Appreciate ID recommendations

   - Status post 14 day course of empiric flagyl (last day today) for

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia. She was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver enzymes. She has undergone tracheostomy and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has been experiencing periods of agitation and has been sedated with Haldol and Midazolam. She has also been receiving antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and bacteremia.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.3C, heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 139/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. Her laboratory results show mild anemia, eosinophilia, and elevated liver enzymes.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Respiratory failure: Continue to trial T-piece with PS 0 and wean sedation gradually.
2. Fevers and bacteremia: Continue to monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary.
3. EtOH abuse: Continue to taper sedation and transition to alternative medications.
4. Distended and thickened gallbladder: Plan for cholecystectomy in 5-6 weeks.
5. Anemia: Monitor HCT and consider iron supplementation.
6. Elevated INR: Continue to monitor INR and adjust Vitamin K therapy as necessary.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, respiratory distress, and respiratory failure.
2. Fevers and bacteremia: Sepsis, organ dysfunction, and mortality.
3. EtOH abuse: Withdrawal symptoms, seizures, and cardiovascular complications.
4. Distended and thickened gallbladder: Cholangitis, pancreatitis, and gallstone formation.
5. Anemia: Hemorrhage, infection, and cardiovascular complications.
6. Elevated INR: Bleeding, hemorrhage, and cardiovascular complications.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

1. Nutrition: Peptamen 1.5 (Full) at 45 mL/hour.
2. Glycemic control: Monitor blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
3. Lines: Monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary.
4. Prophylaxis: Monitor for signs of DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is unknown at this time.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an outside hospital for pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver function tests. She is currently intubated and on a tracheostomy, with a diagnosis of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and suspected c. difficile infection.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7C, heart rate of 78 beats per minute, blood pressure of 127/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. Her laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.9, hemoglobin of 7.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 622. Her liver function tests are elevated, with an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 106 IU/L and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 0.3 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 99%. She is on a tracheostomy and receiving ventilator support.

The patient's medical history includes pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver function tests, as well as a history of alcohol abuse and hyperlipidemia. She has also had a recent episode of fever, which was attributed to VAP.

The patient's medications include fentanyl patch, haloperidol, diazepam, and vancomycin, which are being used to manage her pain, agitation, and infection.

The patient's plan of care includes continued weaning from the ventilator, weaning from sedation, and treatment of VAP with meropenem. She will also continue to receive nutrition support through tube feeding, and her blood glucose levels will be monitored and managed as necessary.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's diagnosis of VAP and the presence of bilateral pleural effusions and bibasal atelectasis suggest that she may be at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and fever suggest that she may be at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's history of pancreatitis and the presence of gallbladder edema suggest that she may be at risk for developing pancreatitis.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver function tests suggest that she may be at risk for developing liver dysfunction.
5. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated creatinine level suggests that she may be at risk for developing renal dysfunction.
6. Anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level suggests that she may be at risk for developing anemia.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's elevated eosinophil count suggests that she may be at risk for developing eosinophilia.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but she is at risk for developing various medical complications. Close monitoring and management of her condition are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory failure:
    - Weaned to facemask
   - Discontinued fent/versed gtts, on fent patch at 150mcg/hour >
   Continuing to wean sedation from prior team
s plan:
   Haldol appeared to work well with improvement during the day in regards
   to her agitation. Given that the patient tends to become more agitated
   and restless overnight, increased PM haldol dose to 10 mg, and give Q6H
   dosing of 5 mg during the day. Continuing valium 10 mg PO TID, and will
   plan to go up further if needed to wean versed once she is on a stable
   haldol dose (today making additional adjustments). Continuing fentanyl
   patch. Follow ECGs
   - Continue to work on diuresis goal about 500cc-1000cc.
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment as noted below.
   - 1:1 sitter to help re-orient patient to ensure safety of her lines
   and tracheostomy and hopefully further safely wean sedation since this
   has been a major barrier.
   - Speech consult for assistance with PMV once she tolerates trach mask,
   which may help patient speak and become more oriented, less agitated.
   .
   #) Fevers, bacteremia:
   Continues to have intermittent low grade temperatures (100), but as
   noted yesterday, fever curve appears to be improving.
   She has had fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**]. Work up has included a TTE which
   was negative for abscess or vegetation. Lines have been changed and
   PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound revealed there was not
   enough fluid for a paracentesis last week, and again this was
   consistent with CT completed last week. Bandemia appeared to have
   improved since initiation of flagyl. She has completed 14 day course of
   zosyn ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which covered entercoccous in one blood culture.
   Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia,
   especially given klebseilla in sputum.
   - Appreciate ID recommendations
   - Following all culture data, including surveillance cultures.
   - Status post 14 day course of empiric flagyl (last day today) for
   question of c. difficile infection.
   - Given sensitivities and imaging, cipro stopped. Sputum klebsiella is
   very sensitive to meropenem for VAP.
   - Will continue vancomycin for gram positive blood cultures which were
   coagulase negative staph until sensitivities return. Given that she has
   had two positive cultures, cannot solely attribute this to
   contamination, however surveillance cultures have been negative. Prior
   TTE was negative, but will need to consider repeat if patient remains
   febrile or additional culture return positive.
   - PLAN: Meropenem for 8 day total course (Klebs), vanco remains
   .
   #) EtOH abuse: Last known drink was PM of [**10-24**]. Sedation taper and
   transition as noted above. Folate and thiamine supplementation. Social
   work consult once more awake and on PMV.
   .
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder:  No acute issues at present. Her
   cholecystitis has been felt to be related to edema from her
   pancreatitis, and no stones have been seen on repeated imaging. At OSH,
   a percutaneous drain was placed out of concern for possible
   cholangitis, revealed only bile. Patient has since pulled out the
   percutaneous tube, and no further intervention has been deemed
   necessary; surgical team has since removed the suture material that
   remained.
   -          Cholecystectomy in [**5-9**] weeks after recovers from acute
   illness.
   .
   #) Anemia: Stable HCT this week, improving to 24.. No evidence of
   bleeding currently, and she has not had any evidence of a hemorrhagic
   component of her pancreatitis noted on CT previously. Phlebotomy is
   likely playing at least a small role as well. No evidence of hemorrhage
   on repeat imaging study. Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, DIC labs
   all checked, iron studies consistent with anemia of chronic disease,
   B12/folate WNL.
   - HCT stable, continuing to follow trend.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, patient
s INR had slowly trended upward,
   suspect likely secondary to nutritional deficiencies given that patient
   was NPO, then only on TPN. She has received Vitamin K.

   #) Eosinophilia: Will continue to trend qOD, ?medication related.
   .

   .

   feeds

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs. She was intubated for increased work of breathing and has a tracheostomy. The patient has been weaned off sedation and is currently on a fentanyl patch at 150mcg/hour. She has a history of fevers, bacteremia, and ventilator-associated pneumonia, and is being treated with antibiotics. The patient also has anemia, elevated INR, and eosinophilia, which are being monitored. She is receiving tube feeds and has a percutaneous drain in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and she is at risk of further respiratory failure due to her underlying condition and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Bacteremia: The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk of developing further infections, particularly in the setting of prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia, which can be a serious complication of mechanical ventilation.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to her underlying condition and the need for repeated phlebotomy, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR is likely related to nutritional deficiencies and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia is likely related to medication and may require further evaluation and treatment.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of pancreatitis and gallbladder edema, which may increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Sepsis: The patient has a history of fevers and bacteremia, which may increase her risk of developing sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust her ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to treat the patient's bacteremia and ventilator-associated pneumonia with antibiotics and other necessary therapies.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider further evaluation and treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's elevated INR and consider further evaluation and treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's eosinophilia and consider further evaluation and treatment as necessary.
6. Consider further evaluation and treatment of the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding risk.
7. Consider further evaluation and treatment of the patient's sepsis risk.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary can be made:

The patient is a 66-year-old female admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of anxiety and pancreatitis. She has been receiving treatment for pancreatitis, including antibiotics, and has been experiencing symptoms of nausea and vomiting. Her anxiety has been controlled with the use of haloperidol, but she is now requesting more anxiety medication.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 147/87 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2. She is receiving IV fluids and has a fluid balance of 2,378 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein levels, indicating an active inflammatory response. Her liver enzymes are elevated, with an ALT of 595 U/L and an AST of 95 U/L. Her renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 29 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show no evidence of pneumonia, and her microbiology results are pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further complications such as sepsis, organ failure, or death.
2. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein levels may indicate an active infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
3. Liver failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver damage or failure, which could lead to coagulopathy, bleeding, or death.
4. Renal failure: The patient's impaired renal function may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Anxiety and panic: The patient's anxiety and panic may worsen, leading to further complications such as agitation, aggression, or self-harm.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition may worsen, leading to further complications such as weakness, fatigue, or poor wound healing.
7. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility may lead to pressure ulcers, which could become infected or worsen.
8. Pneumonia: Despite the lack of imaging evidence, the patient may still develop pneumonia, which could lead to further complications such as sepsis, organ failure, or death.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory failure:
   Related to anxity/need for sedation and hypoventilation, as well as
   suspected and treated VAP
    - Weaned to trachmaskmask
   - Discontinued fent/versed gtts, on fent patch at 150mcg/hour
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be recering from VAP slowly. Cont to wean off trach mask
   Continuing to wean sedation from prior team
s plan:
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia treatment as noted below.
   - 1:1 sitter to help re-orient patient to ensure safety of her lines
   and tracheostomy and hopefully further safely wean sedation since this
   has been a major barrier.
   - PMV trial yesterday went well.
                                                                      over
   #) Fevers, bacteremia:
   She has had fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**], now only low-grade temps.. Work up
   has included a TTE which was negative for abscess or vegetation. Lines
   have been changed and PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound
   revealed there was not enough fluid for a paracentesis last week, and
   again this was consistent with CT completed last week. Bandemia
   appeared to have improved since initiation of flagyl. She has completed
   14 day course of zosyn ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which covered entercoccous in one
   blood culture.
   Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia,
   especially given klebseilla in sputum.
   - continues with low-grade temps.
   - WBC trending back down from 13.9.
   - Appreciate ID recommendations
   - Following all culture data, including surveillance cultures.
   - Status post 14 day course of empiric flagyl (last day today) for
   question of c. difficile infection.
   - Given sensitivities and imaging, cipro stopped. Sputum klebsiella is
   very sensitive to meropenem for VAP.
   - Will continue vancomycin for gram positive blood cultures which were
   coagulase negative staph until sensitivities return. Given that she has
   had two positive cultures, cannot solely attribute this to
   contamination, however surveillance cultures have been negative. Prior
   TTE was negative, but will need to consider repeat if patient remains
   febrile or additional culture return positive.
   - PLAN: VANC/[**Last Name (un) **] through 10/18per  ID recs.
   .
   #)  Agitation / EtOH abuse: Last known drink was PM of [**10-24**]. Sedation
   taper and transition as noted above. Folate and thiamine
   supplementation. Social work consult once more awake and on PMV.
   -          requires sedation with valium, methadone. Taper methadone
   down to q12h, discont standing haldol, and wean off these meds.
   -          Consider psych consult as patient becomes more awake
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder:  No acute issues at present. Her
   cholecystitis has been felt to be related to edema from her
   pancreatitis, and no stones have been seen on repeated imaging. At OSH,
   a percutaneous drain was placed out of concern for possible
   cholangitis, revealed only bile. Patient has since pulled out the
   percutaneous tube, and no further intervention has been deemed
   necessary; surgical team has since removed the suture material that
   remained.
   -          Cholecystectomy in [**5-9**] weeks after recovers from acute
   illness.
   #) Anemia: Stable HCT this week, improving to 24.. No evidence of
   bleeding currently, and she has not had any evidence of a hemorrhagic
   component of her pancreatitis noted on CT previously. Phlebotomy is
   likely playing at least a small role as well. No evidence of hemorrhage
   on repeat imaging study. Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, DIC labs
   all checked, iron studies consistent with anemia of chronic disease,
   B12/folate WNL.
   - HCT stable, continuing to follow trend.
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, patient
s INR had slowly trended upward,
   suspect likely secondary to nutritional deficiencies given that patient
   was NPO, then only on TPN. She has received Vitamin K.
   #) Eosinophilia: Will continue to trend qOD, ?medication related.
   #) GERD: PO PPI
   #) FEN: Tube
   feeds
   #) PPx: On PPI (hx GERD), pneumoboots
   #) Code: Full, confirmed with patient.
   #) Communication: Family (mother and father), mom [**Name (NI) 251**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 2180**]. Family visited yesterday, provided letter documenting that pt
   is critically ill and in the ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred to the ICU for pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver enzymes. She was intubated for increased work of breathing and has a tracheostomy. The patient has been experiencing anxiety, agitation, and fevers, and has been treated with antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). She has also been receiving sedation and pain management medications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been treated with antibiotics for suspected VAP, but the infection may not be fully cleared, and the patient may be at risk for further complications.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient has a history of pancreatitis, and the condition may not be fully resolved, which could lead to further complications, such as pancreatic necrosis or abscesses.
3. Gallbladder complications: The patient has a distended and thickened gallbladder, which may be related to edema from her pancreatitis. The gallbladder may be at risk for further complications, such as cholangitis or cholecystitis.
4. Anemia: The patient has a stable hemoglobin level, but may be at risk for further anemia due to ongoing bleeding or nutritional deficiencies.
5. Elevated INR: The patient's INR has been trending upward, which may be related to nutritional deficiencies or other underlying conditions.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient has an elevated eosinophil count, which may be related to medication or an underlying condition.
7. GERD: The patient has a history of GERD and is receiving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for treatment.
8. FEN: The patient is receiving tube feeds, which may be at risk for complications, such as aspiration or infection.
9. PPx: The patient has a history of pneumoboots, which may be related to her pancreatitis or other underlying conditions.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring her for potential complications and adjusting her treatment plan as necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for
   pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated LFTs, intubated for
   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory failure/VAP:
   Related to anxity/need for sedation and hypoventilation, as well as
   suspected and treated VAP
   - Continue [**Last Name (un) **] for VAP/Klebs
    - Weaned to trachmask, still somewhat hypoxic requiring 50%TM
   - Discontinued fent/versed gtts, on fent patch at 150mcg/hour
   - PMV trial yesterday went well. She is using it well.
                                                                       [**Last Name (un) **]
   #) Coag neg and bacillus bacteremia:
   She has had fevers since [**Date range (1) 2161**], now only low-grade temps.. Work up
   has included a TTE which was negative for abscess or vegetation. Lines
   have been changed and PICC was removed yesterday. Abdominal ultrasound
   revealed there was not enough fluid for a paracentesis last week, and
   again this was consistent with CT completed last week. Bandemia
   appeared to have improved since initiation of flagyl. She has completed
   14 day course of zosyn ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which covered entercoccous in one
   blood culture.
   Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia,
   especially given klebseilla in sputum.
   - Status post 14 day course of empiric flagyl (last day today) for
   question of c. difficile infection, all tests negative
   - continues with low-grade temps.
   - WBC trending back down from 13.9
 10.4
   - Following all culture data, including surveillance cultures.
   - Given sensitivities and imaging, cipro stopped. Sputum klebsiella is
   very sensitive to meropenem for VAP.
   - Will continue vancomycin for gram positive blood cultures which were
   coagulase negative staph until sensitivities return. Given that she has
   had two positive cultures, cannot solely attribute this to
   contamination, however surveillance cultures have been negative. Prior
   TTE was negative, but will need to consider repeat if patient remains
   febrile or additional culture return positive.
   - PLAN: VANC/[**Last Name (un) **] through 10/18per  ID recs.
   .
   #)  Agitation / EtOH abuse: Last known drink was PM of [**10-24**]. Sedation
   taper and transition as noted above. Folate and thiamine
   supplementation. Social work consult once more awake and on PMV.
   -          requires sedation with valium, methadone. Tapered methadone
   down to q12h, discont standing haldol, and wean off these meds.
   -          Consider psych consult as patient becomes more awake
   #) ABD PAIN/Pancreatitis: Ongoing inflammation seen on recent CT. Could
   be residual pancreatitis, though pseudocyst a possibility. Start with
   KUB and can remimage. Abd not impressively tender to palpation at this
   time.
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder:  No acute issues at present. Her
   cholecystitis has been felt to be related to edema from her
   pancreatitis, and no stones have been seen on repeated imaging. At OSH,
   a percutaneous drain was placed out of concern for possible
   cholangitis, revealed only bile. Patient has since pulled out the
   percutaneous tube, and no further intervention has been deemed
   necessary; surgical team has since removed the suture material that
   remained.
   -          Cholecystectomy in [**5-9**] weeks after recovers from acute
   illness.
   -
   #) Anemia: Stable HCT this week, improving to 24.. No evidence of
   bleeding currently, and she has not had any evidence of a hemorrhagic
   component of her pancreatitis noted on CT previously. Phlebotomy is
   likely playing at least a small role as well. No evidence of hemorrhage
   on repeat imaging study. Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, DIC labs
   all checked, iron studies consistent with anemia of chronic disease,
   B12/folate WNL.
   - HCT stable, continuing to follow trend.
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, patient
s INR had slowly trended upward,
   suspect likely secondary to nutritional deficiencies given that patient

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure/VAP: The patient is still somewhat hypoxic requiring 50% TM, and there is a risk of further respiratory failure and VAP.
2. Coagulase-negative and Bacillus bacteremia: The patient has had fevers since admission, and despite treatment, she continues to have low-grade temperatures. There is a risk of further bacteremia and sepsis.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has ongoing inflammation on recent CT scans, which could be residual pancreatitis or a pseudocyst.
4. Distended and thickened gallbladder: The patient has a distended and thickened gallbladder, which could lead to complications such as cholangitis or pancreatitis.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable, but it is likely related to phlebotomy and anemia of chronic disease.
6. Elevated INR: The patient's INR is stable, but it is likely related to nutritional deficiencies and may require further management.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia is ongoing, and it is unclear whether it is related to medication or an underlying condition.
8. GERD: The patient has a history of GERD and is currently receiving PPI therapy.
9. FEN: The patient is receiving tube feeds, which may require further management to prevent complications.
10. PPx: The patient is receiving pneumoboots, which may require further management to prevent complications.

The patient's medical history, current conditions, and potential complications require close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration and ensure optimal care.

   Patient is a 40 year old female with history of pancreatitis, alcohol
   abuse, and hyperlipidemia who was transferred from an OSH for

   increased work of breathing, status post tracheostomy, with continued
   periods of agitation.
   #) Respiratory Status: Stable Currently on 50% trach mask.   Should be
   reassessed for trach removal.
   #) Coag neg and bacillus bacteremia: MSSE bacteremia [**11-9**]. On
   vancomycin now.  Awaiting sensitivities to determine course of
   vancomycin.  She has completed 14 day course of zosyn ([**Date range (1) 2425**]) which
   covered entercoccous in one blood culture.
   #)VAP: Imaging has been consistent with ventilator-associated
   pneumonia, especially given klebseilla in sputum.
   -Given sensitivities and imaging, cipro stopped. Sputum klebsiella is
   very sensitive to meropenem for VAP.
   -[**Last Name (un) 614**] through [**11-20**] for VAP per ID.
   .

   taper and transition as noted above. Folate and thiamine
   supplementation. Social work consult once more awake and on PMV.
   -requires sedation with valium, methadone. Tapered methadone down to
   q12h, discont standing haldol, and wean off these meds.
   -  Consider psych consult as patient becomes more awake
   #) ABD PAIN/Pancreatitis: Ongoing inflammation seen on recent CT. Could
   be residual pancreatitis, though pseudocyst a possibility. Consider abd
   CT next week.
   #) Distended, thickened, gallbladder:  No acute issues at present. Her
   cholecystitis has been felt to be related to edema from her
   pancreatitis, and no stones have been seen on repeated imaging. At OSH,
   a percutaneous drain was placed out of concern for possible
   cholangitis, revealed only bile. Patient has since pulled out the
   percutaneous tube, and no further intervention has been deemed
   necessary; surgical team has since removed the suture material that
   remained.
   -Cholecystectomy in [**5-9**] weeks after recovers from acute illness.
   #) Anemia: Stable HCT this week, improving to 24.. No evidence of
   bleeding currently, and she has not had any evidence of a hemorrhagic
   component of her pancreatitis noted on CT previously. Phlebotomy is
   likely playing at least a small role as well. No evidence of hemorrhage
   on repeat imaging study. Iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis, DIC labs
   all checked, iron studies consistent with anemia of chronic disease,
   B12/folate WNL.
   - HCT stable, continuing to follow trend.
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, patient

   was NPO, then only on TPN. She has received Vitamin K.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia, currently admitted to the ICU for pancreatitis, gallbladder edema, and elevated liver enzymes. She has been intubated for increased work of breathing and has undergone tracheostomy.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.3C (97.4F)
* Heart rate: 79 bpm (68-98 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 137/81 mmHg (92-156/95 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 12 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.3 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 26.2%
* Platelet count: 670 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 101 mg/dL
* Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 101 IU/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 0.3 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 20 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 0.6 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Pancreatitis
* Gallbladder edema
* Elevated liver enzymes
* Hyperlipidemia
* Anemia
* Eosinophilia
* Elevated INR
* GERD
* FEN

The patient's medications include:

* Vancomycin
* Meropenem
* Lansoprazole (Prevacid)
* Heparin sodium
* Morphine
* Dilaudid
* Valium
* Methadone

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Multi-organ failure
* Pancreatitis-related complications (e.g., pseudocyst, abscess)
* Gallbladder-related complications (e.g., cholecystitis, cholangitis)
* Anemia-related complications (e.g., bleeding, infection)
* Eosinophilia-related complications (e.g., allergic reactions, infections)
* Elevated INR-related complications (e.g., bleeding, thrombosis)
* GERD-related complications (e.g., esophagitis, aspiration)
* FEN-related complications (e.g., infection, malnutrition)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Management of pancreatitis and gallbladder edema
* Treatment of anemia and eosinophilia
* Management of elevated INR
* Treatment of GERD and FEN
* Monitoring for respiratory failure and sepsis
* Consideration of cholecystectomy in 5 weeks
* Follow-up with social work and psych consult as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, and hyperlipidemia. She was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure/VAP, coagulase-negative and Bacillus bacteremia, agitation/EtOH abuse, abdominal pain/pancreatitis, distended and thickened gallbladder, anemia, elevated INR, eosinophilia, GERD, and FEN.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure/VAP: Continued hypoxia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and potential for further respiratory decline.
2. Coagulase-negative and Bacillus bacteremia: Development of sepsis, organ dysfunction, and potential for further bacteremia or endocarditis.
3. Agitation/EtOH abuse: Continued agitation, sedation-related complications, and potential for withdrawal symptoms.
4. Abdominal pain/pancreatitis: Ongoing inflammation, potential for pseudocyst formation, and risk of complications such as bleeding, infection, or rupture.
5. Distended and thickened gallbladder: Potential for cholangitis, cholecystitis, or biliary obstruction, especially if stones are present.
6. Anemia: Continued decline in hemoglobin levels, potential for bleeding complications, and risk of organ dysfunction.
7. Elevated INR: Continued risk of bleeding complications, especially if the patient is on anticoagulation therapy.
8. Eosinophilia: Potential for eosinophilic pneumonia, allergic reactions, or other eosinophil-related complications.
9. GERD: Continued risk of aspiration, respiratory complications, and potential for further gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. FEN: Potential for tube-related complications, such as infection, obstruction, or dislodgement.

The patient's plan of care includes ongoing management of her respiratory failure/VAP, coagulase-negative and Bacillus bacteremia, agitation/EtOH abuse, abdominal pain/pancreatitis, distended and thickened gallbladder, anemia, elevated INR, eosinophilia, GERD, and FEN. She will continue to receive antibiotics for her bacteremia, sedation for her agitation, and pain management for her abdominal pain. The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU pending improvement in oxygenation.
